page.title: 02St. Mary's Church, Plumtree
page.content: {The Church of St. Mary the Virgin, {Plumtree, Nottinghamshire.} St Mary's is one of the oldest parish churches in Nottinghamshire and was recorded in the original Domesday Book. Saxon stonework can be seen at both ends of the nave. The tower is early Norman, of the 11th century, and built up against an earlier Saxon wall. The tower holds three, regularly rung, seventeenth century bells. The treble, cast in 1609, the second cast in 1620, and the tenor, cast in 1621 were products of the Oldfield family, owners of Long Row bell_foundry, the major bell-founding centre of the midlands in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries. The North aisle was originally 13th century, but was entirely rebuilt with stone from the old Trent Bridge.
